<p><strong>Sometimes, the whole is less</strong> than the sum of its parts. At least that is the belief underpinning structural separationsplitting an integrated telco operator into two freestanding businesses: one that operates the network (the NetCo) and one customer-facing entity (the ServCo). The idea is that the resulting units will perform better by clarifying management focus and improving capital allocation, given the fundamentally different nature of these two businesses. The hope, also, is that such a move will create a market structure that requires less regulatory intervention.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>The concept of separation in the telecommunications industry has been around for over two decades, though for most of that time, it has been the governments decision to mandate it, not the telcos choice to pursue it. Yet integrated incumbents are beginning to embrace or at least consider separation voluntarily as a way to address deepening financial and market pressures as required infrastructure funding increases dramatically in the face of the investment-heavy evolution toward 5G and fiber to the home. So far, only a few telcos have fully taken the plunge. But with the telecom sector facing headwinds, structural separation is becoming a more frequently discussed topic of major industry stakeholders. </p>
<p>For management, boards, shareholders, and regulators pondering the prospect of separation, the central questions remain: Can breaking up a telco create more value in the long-term? Is doing so worth the risk? And how can telcos minimize that risk?</p>
<h2>The Czech case for separation </h2>
<p>Separation can take different forms, from accounting separation (the simplest and most basic) to functional separation (where the wholesale and retail businesses are set up as independent units) to legal separation (where new legal entities are established but overall ownership remains the same).</p>
<p>The most sweeping change is a full structural separation, which entails creating two distinct legal entities. Historically, most such splits have been the consequence of government action, as a way for regulators to address perceived deep-rooted market inefficiencies resulting from having one entity, often the former state-run monopoly, dominate the telco market. While a few incumbents have considered breakups on a voluntary basis, most have ultimately opted against this path given the massive complexities involved. </p>
<p>That is starting to change. In 2014, O2 in the Czech Republic showed that pursuing structural separation voluntarily could generate superior stakeholder returns while greatly improving the infrastructure of the country. Four years later, Denmarks TDC Group was acquired by a Macquarie-led consortium of buyers at a 34 percent premium to the market price with a structural separation initiative as one of the core pillars of value creation justifying the takeover.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined <div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/how-we-help-clients">Technology, Media & Telecommunications Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header></div></div></div>
<p>A detailed examination of the O2 Czech Republic case offers a good illustration of the potential upside of separation. In 2014, PPF Group, a local private-equity fund, bought O2 Czech Republic from Telefnica Group. The new owner separated the network from the retail business and took the infrastructure unit, now named CETIN, private, while keeping the retail unit publicly listed under the O2 Czech Republic name. It didnt take long for the move to pay off for the investors (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/can%20telcos%20create%20more%20value%20by%20breaking%20up/svgz_telcobreakup_ex1-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Separation in the Czech Republic created tremendous value for shareholders." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/can%20telcos%20create%20more%20value%20by%20breaking%20up/svgz_telcobreakup_ex1-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The deal not only benefitted the new owners; the country received a significant infrastructure upgrade as well. The creation of a pure network-infrastructure player lowered borrowing costs and improved capital access such that CETIN increased its network capital expenditures by 40 percent a year after separation. From there on, capital expenditures increased by 13 percent annually. This led to a jump in fiber coverage and broadband speeds at a level rarely seen in Europe (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/can%20telcos%20create%20more%20value%20by%20breaking%20up/svgz_telcobreakup_ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Separation in the Czech Republic has led to a wave of fresh investment in the NetCo, which has resulted in faster broadband speeds" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/can%20telcos%20create%20more%20value%20by%20breaking%20up/svgz_telcobreakup_ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>How separation can pay off</h2>
<p>While the specifics of how PPF Group doubled its money with the O2 Czech Republic separation is a matter of debate, structural separation in general can fuel value creation in the following five ways:</p>
<ol>
    <li><em>Regulatory relief.</em> Since separation invariably alters the existing market structure and typically increases retail competition, most cases result in some form of regulatory relief. There are even EU guidelines for regulations to this effect.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2e47221a-72b3-4453-8f1d-aaf9e2ad4e37"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2e47221a-72b3-4453-8f1d-aaf9e2ad4e37" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">In fact, the new European Communications Code (June 2018) states that regulators shall re-assess, amend or withdraw obligations if separation is voluntarily undertaken (art 76.2). See http://data.consilium.europa.eu/doc/document/ST-10692-2018-INIT/en/pdf.</span></span></span></a></span> Before separation, O2 estimated that retail price regulation impacted roughly 25 percent of its gross margin. The company also faced several predatory pricing cases. With the lifting of these restraints, O2 and CETIN gained greater pricing and contracting flexibility. Removing nationwide retail pricing controls was particularly important in a market where rates vary greatly, given the localized nature of competition.</li>
    <li><em>Greater addressable market.</em> A carrier-neutral NetCo can grow its wholesale business with other operators, since aggregating demand from multiple wholesale customers increases household conversion rates for fiber and, hence, return on investment for new builds. In the O2 case, the carrier-neutral CETIN, untethered from its former parent, grew beyond its original business by adding subscribers and traffic from the customer bases of other operators.</li>
    <li><em>Cheaper access to capital.</em> By operating independently, financing options for the NetCo improve considerably. Since it primarily invests in infrastructure, the NetCo can attract long-term investors who are interested in buying into a physical asset. Similarly, the ServCos investment profile is better suited to investors who are looking for higher risk-adjusted returns. As a result, the multiples for the two entities recalibrate in a way that increases their combined valuation.</li>
    <li><em>Sharpened management focus. </em>Investment horizons differ significantly for the separated entities; NetCos usually plan in ten-to-15-year time frames (for infrastructure investments that can last for 50 to 100 years) while ServCos work with one-to-three-year investment cycles (for commercial activities, such as marketing campaigns and promotions). By separating the NetCo and ServCo, decision makers can direct strategy and budget based squarely on the specific needs of each company, leading to greater strategic clarity and operating momentum. In the case of O2, the increased focus for management translated into higher customer satisfaction ratings for CETIN, and a faster buildout of O2s O2 TV.</li>
    <li><em>Better suited for a 5G world. </em>Although analysts disagree on the exact numbers and magnitude, there is broad consensus that 5G will drive up the total cost of network ownership, given the massively increased densification of urban areas and the resulting heightened requirements on capillarity of fiber deployment. A strong, independent NetCo is better positioned to support the industrys need for fiber rollout than an integrated carrier. As a neutral party, it is also a natural orchestrator for the increased network sharing that 5G is likely to prompt. A recent McKinsey 5G survey found that 93 percent of chief technology officers expect increased network sharing to occur with the onset of 5G.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="925e1d33-3064-4bc4-b801-904fa5421481"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="925e1d33-3064-4bc4-b801-904fa5421481" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ferry Grijpink, Tobias Hrlin, Harrison Lung, and Alexandre Mnard, <a href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/cutting-through-the-5g-hype-survey-shows-telcos-nuanced-views">Cutting through the 5G hype: Survey shows telcos nuanced views</a>, February 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ol>
<h2>Why separation can backfire</h2>
<p>While separation has the potential to generate significant value creation, it is also a high-stakes venture that can destroy value if managed poorly or pursued under the wrong preconditions. By giving up their network ownership ServCos could, for instance, face higher transaction costs in their day-to-day dealings with the NetCo and lose several important advantages, such as:</p>
<ul>
    <li>preferential treatment in fixed deployment through price differentiation or operational integration</li>
    <li>ability to apply similar preferential treatment in mobile through bundling and cross-subsidization</li>
    <li>power to direct NetCo investments into areas that benefit the ServCo, driven by regional market-share differences</li>
    <li>full control of certain types of product development that require deep integration into the network (for example, certain IoT use cases)</li>
</ul>
<p>The extent to which the loss of these advantages will impact the ServCo depends largely on the regulatory frameworks that will be adopted after the separation as well as on the details of the commercial contracts governing relations between the ServCo and the NetCo. </p>
<p>Separation is also costly and time-consuming. British Telecom estimated that a previous functional separation had cost them more than $1 billion,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="30a537c1-3783-4c94-9c38-089487752013"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="30a537c1-3783-4c94-9c38-089487752013" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Strengthening Openreachs strategic and operational independence, Ofcom, July 2016, ofcom.org.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> and historic cases indicate that the process can take anywhere from two to five years, consuming significant management attention, and potentially all but paralyzing leadership. IT systems separation alone can take as long as 18 months, during which time typical product development generally grinds to a halt. </p>
<h2>When separation makes senseor doesnt</h2>
<p>Carefully weighing the pros and cons of separation before making a choice is not simple. Individual markets and operators differ greatly with regard to the parameters that determine the potential upside and downside. Given the irreversible nature of the decision, management, boards and investors should carefully evaluate each of the drivers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8a4678f2-57d5-4910-8ff9-02f78962ac88"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8a4678f2-57d5-4910-8ff9-02f78962ac88" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For a broader overview of separation and spin-offs and key drivers of value creation, see Bill Huyett and Tim Koller, <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/finding-the-courage-to-shrink">Finding the courage to shrink</a>, August 2011.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Are telcos prepared to lay the foundation for the digital future?" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/are%20telcos%20prepared%20to%20lay%20the%20foundation%20for%20the%20digital%20future/mwc19-collection-interactive_1536x1536.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Are telcos prepared to lay the foundation for the digital future?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/are-telcos-prepared-to-lay-the-foundation-for-the-digital-future" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Explore the collection</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>These determinant factors include the scope of the current regulatory environment, which could be reduced as a result of separation and thereby unlock value; the amount of growth potential from increasing investments in infrastructure; and the extent to which the NetCo could play an active role in future network-sharing arrangements. They also include the ability of the ServCo to lock in some post-separation downside protection, such as a limited form of preferential coordination with the NetCo or a clear commercial opportunity on the retail side. Finally, there is the sheer complexity of the undertaking, the time required to complete it, and the sustained management focus required (Exhibit 3).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/can%20telcos%20create%20more%20value%20by%20breaking%20up/svgz_telcobreakup_ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The desirability of separation depends on a number of variables" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/can%20telcos%20create%20more%20value%20by%20breaking%20up/svgz_telcobreakup_ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h2>Getting separation right </h2>
<p>There is no doubt that executing structural separation is one of the most complex and arduous journeys a telco management team can undertake. Yet, done well, it can potentially deliver huge returns. Success stories to date provide a clear picture of the trickiest issues to address. These include:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Asset and activity delineation. </em>Deciding which assets belong to the ServCo and which should transfer to the NetCo is not a trivial exercise. When figuring out how to divide assets, executives need to consider both synergies and downstream implications. In addition to apportioning out core network functionalities and different customer interfaces, they need to address strategic questions such as how spectrum ownership will be assigned, choices that impact how the mobile network is designed and how wholesale capacity decisions are made. </li>
    <li><em>Organization and process redesign.</em> The breakup will require the NetCo and ServCo to create new processes, retrofit other ones, and create efficient information-sharing mechanisms. These efforts are complicated by two factors. First, many processes (such as provisioning) crisscross the incumbents network and customer-facing organizations. Disentangling them requires a comprehensive process redesign effort. Second, integrated players also depend on many informal and undocumented processes in their day-to-day work. Failing to manage the process-redesign effort effectively will almost certainly lead to disruptions in the network operations.</li>
    <li><em>Commercial contract.</em>Creating a commercial contract that governs every activity and service that the NetCo is currently providing to the ServCo is a monumental task. From a transparency and governance standpoint, it is also the most critical way to clarify any advantages the ServCo may forfeit after the split. </li>
    <li><em>IT-systems separation.</em> Each telco has a unique IT setup, usually a patchwork quilt of operations support systems and business support systems, some of them homegrown, most of them integrated across functions that will end up on different sides of the separated entity. Inevitably, some systems will have to be duplicated, some retired, and some built anew. </li>
</ul>
<p>Addressing these changes successfully hinges on two thingstiming and teaming. First, management needs to pay attention to the proper sequencing of tasks. Not all issues can be addressed in parallel, since the resolution of some are prerequisites for tackling others. Secondly, different tasks require very different talent profiles and capabilities. Some tasks, for instance, require significant expertise and analysis. Others require a tolerance for slogging through straightforward but laborious work for weeks or months on end. Still others, like the separation of IT, require both. Shaping the right road map and establishing the right project teams will have a significant bearing on the quality of the outcome (Exhibit 4).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8a51d93a-8363-4089-902a-3b3f89d9d7a2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8a51d93a-8363-4089-902a-3b3f89d9d7a2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sean OConnell, Michael Park, and Jannick Thomsen, <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/divestitures-how-to-invest-for-success">Divestitures: How to invest for success</a>, August 2015 and Obi Ezekoye and Jannick Thomsen, <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/going-going-gone-a-quicker-way-to-divest-assets">Going, going, gone: A quicker way to divest assets</a>, August 2018.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/can%20telcos%20create%20more%20value%20by%20breaking%20up/svgz_telcobreakup_ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="A structured approach is required in defining, negotiating, and documenting all principles toward structural separation" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/telecommunications/our%20insights/can%20telcos%20create%20more%20value%20by%20breaking%20up/svgz_telcobreakup_ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Structural separation offers the potential for significant value creation, but the risks and complexity of carving out deeply interconnected businesses are great as well. While the jury is still out on whether it will become a more widely adopted business model, success depends on a close understanding of the market and regulatory environment, a comprehensive change-management plan, and an investment case that recognizes that separation is a long-term play that requires considerable ramp-up time and downside protection for ServCo businesses.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/gustav-grundin">Gustav Grundin </a></strong>is a partner in the Tokyo office, <strong><a href="/our-people/robin-nuttall">Robin Nuttall </a></strong>is a partner in the London office, <strong>Lorraine Salazar</strong> is an expert in the Singapore office, <strong>Halldor Sigurdsson</strong> is a partner in the Paris office, and <strong>Nemanja Vucevic</strong> is an associate partner in the Madrid office.</p>

aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Can telcos create more value by breaking up","displayName":"Can telcos create more value by breaking up","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"9d6e7023-1b09-490e-bd5d-57368dd690d2","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Can telcos create more value by breaking up?"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Could telecom use structural separation to create more value?"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Once primarily a regulators\u0026rsquo; tool, structural separation is beginning to attract growing interest from operators facing financial and market pressures."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Telcos are increasingly looking at divestiture and structural separation as a possible solution to financial challenges."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2020-01-22T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSometimes, the whole is less\u003c/strong\u003e than the sum of its parts. At least that is the belief underpinning structural separation\u0026mdash;splitting an integrated telco operator into two freestanding businesses: one that operates the network (the NetCo) and one customer-facing entity (the ServCo). The idea is that the resulting units will perform better by clarifying management focus and improving capital allocation, given the fundamentally different nature of these two businesses. The hope, also, is that such a move will create a market structure that requires less regulatory intervention.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe concept of separation in the telecommunications industry has been around for over two decades, though for most of that time, it has been the government\u0026rsquo;s decision to mandate it, not the telco\u0026rsquo;s choice to pursue it. Yet integrated incumbents are beginning to embrace or at least consider separation voluntarily as a way to address deepening financial and market pressures as required infrastructure funding increases dramatically in the face of the investment-heavy evolution toward 5G and fiber to the home. So far, only a few telcos have fully taken the plunge. But with the telecom sector facing headwinds, structural separation is becoming a more frequently discussed topic of major industry stakeholders. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor management, boards, shareholders, and regulators pondering the prospect of separation, the central questions remain: Can breaking up a telco create more value in the long-term? Is doing so worth the risk? And how can telcos minimize that risk?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe Czech case for separation \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeparation can take different forms, from accounting separation (the simplest and most basic) to functional separation (where the wholesale and retail businesses are set up as independent units) to legal separation (where new legal entities are established but overall ownership remains the same).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe most sweeping change is a full structural separation, which entails creating two distinct legal entities. Historically, most such splits have been the consequence of government action, as a way for regulators to address perceived deep-rooted market inefficiencies resulting from having one entity, often the former state-run monopoly, dominate the telco market. While a few incumbents have considered breakups on a voluntary basis, most have ultimately opted against this path given the massive complexities involved. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat is starting to change. In 2014, O2 in the Czech Republic showed that pursuing structural separation voluntarily could generate superior stakeholder returns while greatly improving the infrastructure of the country. Four years later, Denmark\u0026rsquo;s TDC Group was acquired by a Macquarie-led consortium of buyers at a 34 percent premium to the market price with a structural separation initiative as one of the core pillars of value creation justifying the takeover.[[Footnote 1]] Telecom Italia[[Footnote 2]] in 2018 started to evaluate the possibility of setting up a separate NetCo, and that same year Telstra[[Footnote 3]] came out with plans to establish a separate infrastructure business unit. Meanwhile, shareholders or board members of at least two other carriers, British Telecom[[Footnote 4]] and Telefonica,[[Footnote 5]] requested their companies consider the same.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003eA detailed examination of the O2 Czech Republic case offers a good illustration of the potential upside of separation. In 2014, PPF Group, a local private-equity fund, bought O2 Czech Republic from Telef\u0026oacute;nica Group. The new owner separated the network from the retail business and took the infrastructure unit, now named CETIN, private, while keeping the retail unit publicly listed under the O2 Czech Republic name. It didn\u0026rsquo;t take long for the move to pay off for the investors (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe deal not only benefitted the new owners; the country received a significant infrastructure upgrade as well. The creation of a pure network-infrastructure player lowered borrowing costs and improved capital access such that CETIN increased its network capital expenditures by 40 percent a year after separation. From there on, capital expenditures increased by 13 percent annually. This led to a jump in fiber coverage and broadband speeds at a level rarely seen in Europe (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003ch2\u003eHow separation can pay off\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile the specifics of how PPF Group doubled its money with the O2 Czech Republic separation is a matter of debate, structural separation in general can fuel value creation in the following five ways:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRegulatory relief.\u003c/em\u003e Since separation invariably alters the existing market structure and typically increases retail competition, most cases result in some form of regulatory relief. There are even EU guidelines for regulations to this effect.[[Footnote 6]] Before separation, O2 estimated that retail price regulation impacted roughly 25 percent of its gross margin. The company also faced several predatory pricing cases. With the lifting of these restraints, O2 and CETIN gained greater pricing and contracting flexibility. Removing nationwide retail pricing controls was particularly important in a market where rates vary greatly, given the localized nature of competition.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eGreater addressable market.\u003c/em\u003e A carrier-neutral NetCo can grow its wholesale business with other operators, since aggregating demand from multiple wholesale customers increases household conversion rates for fiber and, hence, return on investment for new builds. In the O2 case, the carrier-neutral CETIN, untethered from its former parent, grew beyond its original business by adding subscribers and traffic from the customer bases of other operators.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCheaper access to capital.\u003c/em\u003e By operating independently, financing options for the NetCo improve considerably. Since it primarily invests in infrastructure, the NetCo can attract long-term investors who are interested in buying into a physical asset. Similarly, the ServCo\u0026rsquo;s investment profile is better suited to investors who are looking for higher risk-adjusted returns. As a result, the multiples for the two entities recalibrate in a way that increases their combined valuation.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eSharpened management focus. \u003c/em\u003eInvestment horizons differ significantly for the separated entities; NetCos usually plan in ten-to-15-year time frames (for infrastructure investments that can last for 50 to 100 years) while ServCos work with one-to-three-year investment cycles (for commercial activities, such as marketing campaigns and promotions). By separating the NetCo and ServCo, decision makers can direct strategy and budget based squarely on the specific needs of each company, leading to greater strategic clarity and operating momentum. In the case of O2, the increased focus for management translated into higher customer satisfaction ratings for CETIN, and a faster buildout of O2\u0026rsquo;s O2 TV.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBetter suited for a 5G world. \u003c/em\u003eAlthough analysts disagree on the exact numbers and magnitude, there is broad consensus that 5G will drive up the total cost of network ownership, given the massively increased densification of urban areas and the resulting heightened requirements on capillarity of fiber deployment. A strong, independent NetCo is better positioned to support the industry\u0026rsquo;s need for fiber rollout than an integrated carrier. As a neutral party, it is also a natural orchestrator for the increased network sharing that 5G is likely to prompt. A recent McKinsey 5G survey found that 93 percent of chief technology officers expect increased network sharing to occur with the onset of 5G.[[Footnote 7]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhy separation can backfire\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile separation has the potential to generate significant value creation, it is also a high-stakes venture that can destroy value if managed poorly or pursued under the wrong preconditions. By giving up their network ownership ServCos could, for instance, face higher transaction costs in their day-to-day dealings with the NetCo and lose several important advantages, such as:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003epreferential treatment in fixed deployment through price differentiation or operational integration\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eability to apply similar preferential treatment in mobile through bundling and cross-subsidization\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003epower to direct NetCo investments into areas that benefit the ServCo, driven by regional market-share differences\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003efull control of certain types of product development that require deep integration into the network (for example, certain IoT use cases)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe extent to which the loss of these advantages will impact the ServCo depends largely on the regulatory frameworks that will be adopted after the separation as well as on the details of the commercial contracts governing relations between the ServCo and the NetCo. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeparation is also costly and time-consuming. British Telecom estimated that a previous functional separation had cost them more than $1 billion,[[Footnote 8]] and historic cases indicate that the process can take anywhere from two to five years, consuming significant management attention, and potentially all but paralyzing leadership. IT systems separation alone can take as long as 18 months, during which time typical product development generally grinds to a halt. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhen separation makes sense\u0026mdash;or doesn\u0026rsquo;t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCarefully weighing the pros and cons of separation before making a choice is not simple. Individual markets and operators differ greatly with regard to the parameters that determine the potential upside and downside. Given the irreversible nature of the decision, management, boards and investors should carefully evaluate each of the drivers.[[Footnote 9]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis3]]\n\u003cp\u003eThese determinant factors include the scope of the current regulatory environment, which could be reduced as a result of separation and thereby unlock value; the amount of growth potential from increasing investments in infrastructure; and the extent to which the NetCo could play an active role in future network-sharing arrangements. They also include the ability of the ServCo to lock in some post-separation downside protection, such as a limited form of preferential coordination with the NetCo or a clear commercial opportunity on the retail side. Finally, there is the sheer complexity of the undertaking, the time required to complete it, and the sustained management focus required (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003ch2\u003eGetting separation right \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere is no doubt that executing structural separation is one of the most complex and arduous journeys a telco management team can undertake. Yet, done well, it can potentially deliver huge returns. Success stories to date provide a clear picture of the trickiest issues to address. These include:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAsset and activity delineation. \u003c/em\u003eDeciding which assets belong to the ServCo and which should transfer to the NetCo is not a trivial exercise. When figuring out how to divide assets, executives need to consider both synergies and downstream implications. In addition to apportioning out core network functionalities and different customer interfaces, they need to address strategic questions such as how spectrum ownership will be assigned, choices that impact how the mobile network is designed and how wholesale capacity decisions are made. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eOrganization and process redesign.\u003c/em\u003e The breakup will require the NetCo and ServCo to create new processes, retrofit other ones, and create efficient information-sharing mechanisms. These efforts are complicated by two factors. First, many processes (such as provisioning) crisscross the incumbent\u0026rsquo;s network and customer-facing organizations. Disentangling them requires a comprehensive process redesign effort. Second, integrated players also depend on many informal and undocumented processes in their day-to-day work. Failing to manage the process-redesign effort effectively will almost certainly lead to disruptions in the network operations.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCommercial contract.\u003c/em\u003eCreating a commercial contract that governs every activity and service that the NetCo is currently providing to the ServCo is a monumental task. From a transparency and governance standpoint, it is also the most critical way to clarify any advantages the ServCo may forfeit after the split. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIT-systems separation.\u003c/em\u003e Each telco has a unique IT setup, usually a patchwork quilt of operations support systems and business support systems, some of them homegrown, most of them integrated across functions that will end up on different sides of the separated entity. Inevitably, some systems will have to be duplicated, some retired, and some built anew. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAddressing these changes successfully hinges on two things\u0026mdash;timing and teaming. First, management needs to pay attention to the proper sequencing of tasks. Not all issues can be addressed in parallel, since the resolution of some are prerequisites for tackling others. Secondly, different tasks require very different talent profiles and capabilities. Some tasks, for instance, require significant expertise and analysis. Others require a tolerance for slogging through straightforward but laborious work for weeks or months on end. Still others, like the separation of IT, require both. Shaping the right road map and establishing the right project teams will have a significant bearing on the quality of the outcome (Exhibit 4).[[Footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eStructural separation offers the potential for significant value creation, but the risks and complexity of carving out deeply interconnected businesses are great as well. While the jury is still out on whether it will become a more widely adopted business model, success depends on a close understanding of the market and regulatory environment, a comprehensive change-management plan, and an investment case that recognizes that separation is a long-term play that requires considerable ramp-up time and downside protection for ServCo businesses.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2020-01-22T21:30:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Denmark\u0026rsquo;s TDC to be split into three units\u0026mdash;Macquarie-led consortium,\u0026rdquo;
